metadata.titleEn: Soil  Erodibility Factor (K) Dataset of Pan-Third Pole 65 countries (2021)
metadata.description: The soil erodibility factor (K) dataset of the pan-third pole area  is calculated based on the soil properties downloaded from website of the international soil reference and Information Center (ISRIC)（https://files.isric.org/soilgrids/latest/data/） with 7.5 arc second resolution. And the dataset used in the calculation includes soil clay content (%), silt content (%), and sand content (%), soil organic carbon content (g / kg) and soil texture class. By usint the soil erodibility factor algorithm proposed by Wischmeier (1978) in the second edition of USLE manual and the soil erodibility factor calculation tool (k_tool) developed in this project, a soil erodibility factor map was generated with a resolution of  30 arc second (about 1000m) . The soil erodibility factor data of Pan third pole 65 countries is the essential data for calculating soil erosion rate based on CSLE, it is also the basic data for analyzing soil characteristics.
metadata.instructions: Da200402022-k65.zip: xda20040202 is the sub subject number, 2 is the sub subject number, K represents soil erodibility factor, and 65 represents 65 countries; TIFF format can be opened and analyzed by general GIS software (such as ArcGIS) or image processing software (such as envi).

background: Rock fragments (>2 mm diameter) are an important component of soil, and its presence has a significant impact on soil erosion and sediment yield. So it is essential to take into full account content of the rock fragments for accurate calculation of soil erodibility factor (K). Soil erodibility factor (K) is a basic parameter in models like USLE, RUSLE, EPIC, and AGNPS, and its value is essential data for regional soil erosion surveys and mapping using models like USLE/CSLE. Since Wischmeier formally proposed the soil erodibility factor (K), numerous studies have been conducted both domestically and internationally, resulting in several methods for estimating soil erodibility factors. Mature algorithms include the USLE-K algorithm, RUSLE2-K algorithm, EPIC-K algorithm, and algorithms based on average geometric particle size. These algorithms calculate the soil erodibility K value based on soil physical and chemical properties (particle size, organic matter, structure, and permeability, etc.). A large body of research indicates that the content of rock fragments in the soil profile and rock fragment cover on the soil surface significantly affect soil hydrology, soil erosion and sediment yield processes, and land use. Brakensiek et al. established a method for estimating saturated hydraulic conductivity based on the content of rock fragments in the profile. Poesen et al. demonstrated that rock fragment cover on the soil surface can reduce soil erodibility and can be quantitatively estimated using an exponential decay function. Zhou and Shao found that when the content of rock fragments in the soil exceeds 40%, the soil infiltration rate decreases, and the soil's saturated hydraulic conductivity increases. Jomaa et al.'s laboratory flume experiments showed that rock fragment cover can mitigate raindrop impact, reduce surface water flow, and decrease runoff transport capacity, thereby reducing soil erosion. Hlaváčiková et al. discovered that rock fragments in the profile can reduce saturated hydraulic conductivity, thereby increasing surface runoff and erosion sediment yield.
research objective: In this paper, based on the data available of the content of rock fragments and classes of soil texture with a resolution of 30 arc-second, influence of the content of rock fragments, including rock fragments in the soil profile (RFP) and gravels on the surface of the soil (SC), on K was assessed at a global scale, using the equation (Brakensiek, 1986) of the relationship between saturated hydraulic conductivity and grade of soil permeability, and the equation (Poesen) of soil erodibility attenuation under a rock fragment cover. The joint effect of rock fragments in profile and gravels on the surface reduced the soil erosion rate by 11.8% in the 6 sample areas. In plotting regional soil erosion maps, it is essential to take both of the two into account so as to improve accuracy of the mapping.
challenges: Despite Römkens et al. mentioning the influence of rock fragments on soil erodibility factors in the RUSLE manual and decomposing it into the effects of rock fragment content in the soil profile and rock fragment cover on the soil surface, studies on soil erodibility factor calculation and mapping have not considered the impact of profile rock fragments and rock fragment cover on soil erodibility. To date, there is still no global correction method and result for the calculation value of soil erodibility factors considering rock fragment content.
methods: In this paper, based on the data available of the content of rock fragments and classes of soil texture with a resolution of 30 arc-second, influence of the content of rock fragments, including rock fragments in the soil profile (RFP) and gravels on the surface of the soil (SC), on K was assessed at a global scale, using the equation (Brakensiek, 1986) of the relationship between saturated hydraulic conductivity and grade of soil permeability, and the equation (Poesen) of soil erodibility attenuation under a rock fragment cover.
dataset: The basic data used in this study is SoilGrids released by ISRIC, including soil type maps and soil property maps (surface layer 0-15 cm and soil surface), etc. The latest version of this data has an original resolution of 7.5 arc seconds, which was resampled to 30 arc seconds during the analysis process.
findings: Results show: (1) The existence of rock fragments in the soil increased K by 4.43% and soil permeability by 5.68% on average in grade and lowering soil saturated hydraulic conductivity by 11.57% by reducing water infiltration rate of the soil and increasing surface runoff. The gravels on the surface of the mountain land and desert/gobi reduced K by 18.7% by protecting the soil from splashing of rain drops and scrubbing of runoff; so once the content of rock fragments in the soil profile and gravels on the surface of the land are taken into account in calculation, soil K may be 5.52% lower; (2) In the areas dominated with the effect of rock fragments, about 62.7% of the global land area, soil K decreased by 0.0091(t·hm2·h)·(hm–2·MJ–1·mm–1) on average, while in the area affected mainly by rock fragments in profile, about 31.1% of the global land area, soil K increased by 0.0019(t·hm2·h)·(hm–2·MJ–1·mm–1); and (3) The joint effect of rock fragments in profile and gravels on the surface reduced the soil erosion rate by 11.8% in the 6 sample areas.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of a challenge faced when calculating soil erodibility factors (K) that take into account the rock fragment content?
Example.Answer: One example of a challenge is the lack of a global correction method for calculating soil erodibility factors that consider the content of rock fragments. Definition.Question: What is the significance of soil erodibility factor (K) in soil erosion models?
Definition.Answer: Soil erodibility factor (K) is a basic parameter in models like USLE, RUSLE, EPIC, and AGNPS, and its value is essential data for regional soil erosion surveys and mapping using models like USLE/CSLE. It is calculated based on soil physical and chemical properties, such as particle size, organic matter, structure, and permeability.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges in calculating soil erodibility factor (K) when considering rock fragments?
Definition.Answer: One of the challenges is that despite the known influence of rock fragments on soil erodibility factors, studies have not fully integrated the impact of profile rock fragments and rock fragment cover on soil erodibility. There is still no global correction method for calculating soil erodibility factors that consider rock fragment content.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in datasets required for calculating soil erodibility factor (K) using the USLE-K algorithm versus algorithms based on average geometric particle size?
Comparison.Answer: The USLE-K algorithm primarily requires data on soil physical and chemical properties such as particle size, organic matter, structure, and permeability. In contrast, algorithms based on average geometric particle size may focus more specifically on the geometric distribution of soil particles, potentially requiring different or additional data on soil texture and composition.

Comparison.Question: How does the resolution of soil property data from SoilGrids impact the calculation of soil erodibility factor (K) compared to datasets with different spatial resolutions?
Comparison.Answer: The SoilGrids dataset, originally with a 7.5 arc-second resolution and resampled to 30 arc-second for analysis, provides a higher spatial resolution than some other datasets. This higher resolution allows for more detailed and potentially more accurate calculations of the soil erodibility factor (K), as it can capture finer spatial variations in soil properties.

Interpretation.Question: How might the presence of rock fragments in soil profiles influence the accuracy of soil erodibility factor calculations across different regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The presence of rock fragments in soil profiles can significantly impact the soil erodibility factor calculations by increasing the soil's permeability and lowering saturated hydraulic conductivity, which affects water infiltration and runoff. This variation can lead to different erodibility factors in areas with varying rock fragment content.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in resampling soil data from a higher resolution to a lower one, and how could these affect the interpretation of soil erosion rates?
Interpretation.Answer: Resampling soil data from a higher resolution (7.5 arc seconds) to a lower one (30 arc seconds) may lead to loss of detail and introduction of generalized data points, which can affect the precision of soil erosion rate calculations, potentially overlooking localized variations in soil properties and rock fragment content.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the inclusion of gravel coverage on soil surfaces alter the interpretation of soil erosion data and mapping accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: The inclusion of gravel coverage on soil surfaces can alter the interpretation of soil erosion data by reducing soil erodibility, protecting the soil from raindrop impact and runoff, and thereby lowering the calculated soil erosion rates. This consideration enhances mapping accuracy by accounting for surface protection factors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the lack of global correction methods for calculating soil erodibility factors considering rock fragment content?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in global correction methods arise because existing studies have not fully incorporated the impact of profile rock fragments and rock fragment cover on soil erodibility, despite their recognized influence in specific soil erosion models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the differences in soil erodibility factor (K) values across different global regions when accounting for rock fragment content?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Differences in K values across regions are due to the varying influence of rock fragments in the soil profile and on the surface, which can increase or decrease soil permeability and erosion rates depending on their presence and distribution.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on soil erodibility factor (K) when incorporating data on rock fragments in soil profiles and surface gravels into the calculation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating data on rock fragments in soil profiles and surface gravels into the calculation can lead to an increased soil erodibility factor (K) by 4.43% and enhance soil permeability by 5.68% on average. Additionally, it can decrease soil saturated hydraulic conductivity by 11.57%, affecting the water infiltration rate and increasing surface runoff. The presence of gravels on the surface can further reduce K by 18.7% due to protection against rain and runoff, potentially lowering soil K by 5.52% when both factors are considered.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of soil texture classes and rock fragment content data at a 30 arc-second resolution impact global soil erosion mapping accuracy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including soil texture classes and rock fragment content data at a 30 arc-second resolution impacts global soil erosion mapping accuracy by enabling a more precise assessment of soil erodibility factor (K) changes. The joint effect of rock fragments in the profile and gravels on the surface can lead to an 11.8% reduction in soil erosion rates in sample areas, enhancing the accuracy of regional soil erosion maps by accounting for these variables.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences on soil erosion rate calculations when different algorithms for estimating soil erodibility factors are applied globally?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying different algorithms for estimating soil erodibility factors globally can result in varying consequences on soil erosion rate calculations. For instance, the influence of rock fragments can decrease the soil K value by 0.0091(t·hm2·h)·(hm–2·MJ–1·mm–1) in some regions, while increasing it by 0.0019(t·hm2·h)·(hm–2·MJ–1·mm–1) in others. Overall, the joint effect of rock fragments in the profile and surface gravels can reduce soil erosion rates by 11.8% in specific areas, highlighting the need for algorithmic precision in calculations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives might drive the development of a dataset focusing on soil erodibility factors across diverse global regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective could be to provide essential data for regional soil erosion surveys and improve mapping accuracy using models like USLE/CSLE, by considering variations in soil physical and chemical properties, and rock fragment content.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to incorporate both rock fragments in the soil profile and surface gravels when creating datasets aimed at understanding soil erosion?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Incorporating both factors is important because they jointly affect soil erosion rates by altering soil hydrology, reducing soil erodibility, and thereby impacting the accuracy of soil erosion mapping.

Goal Orientation.Question: What could be the rationale for resampling high-resolution soil data to a lower resolution when creating datasets for large-scale soil erosion analysis?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Resampling to a lower resolution might be necessary to facilitate the integration of soil data with other geospatial datasets, ensure computational efficiency, and match the scale required for regional or global soil erosion analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in resampling soil property data from the original 7.5 arc seconds resolution to 30 arc seconds for analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data from SoilGrids, which originally has a resolution of 7.5 arc seconds, is resampled to a resolution of 30 arc seconds during the analysis process. This involves updating the resolution of the soil type maps and soil property maps, such as the surface layer 0-15 cm and soil surface data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the influence of rock fragments in the soil profile and surface gravels be incorporated into the calculation of the soil erodibility factor (K)?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The influence of rock fragments, including those in the soil profile and gravels on the surface, is assessed using equations like Brakensiek's for the relationship between saturated hydraulic conductivity and soil permeability, and Poesen's equation for soil erodibility attenuation under rock fragment cover. These factors are integrated into the calculation of K to reflect their impact on soil erosion rates.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to evaluate the impact of rock fragment content on soil hydrology and erosion processes globally?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methods include using available data on the content of rock fragments and soil texture classes, with calculations based on relationships such as those defined by Brakensiek and Poesen. These methods assess the effects of rock fragments in the soil profile and on the surface on soil erodibility and hydrology, considering their impact on saturated hydraulic conductivity and surface runoff.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the calculation of soil erodibility factors (K) using data on rock fragments and soil texture classes?
Enablement.Answer: Methodologies such as the USLE-K algorithm, RUSLE2-K algorithm, EPIC-K algorithm, and algorithms based on average geometric particle size enable the calculation of soil erodibility factors (K) by utilizing data on rock fragments and soil texture classes. These methods consider soil physical and chemical properties, including particle size, organic matter, structure, and permeability.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of rock fragment content data influence the accuracy of soil erosion mapping using global datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of rock fragment content data influences the accuracy of soil erosion mapping by accounting for the effects of rock fragments in the soil profile and gravels on the soil surface. This integration can reduce the soil erosion rate by 11.8% in sample areas and improves the accuracy of regional soil erosion maps by considering both profile rock fragments and surface gravels.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are faced in developing global correction methods for soil erodibility factors considering rock fragment content?
Enablement.Answer: One of the challenges in developing global correction methods for soil erodibility factors considering rock fragment content is the lack of a global correction method and result for calculating soil erodibility factors that take into account the content of rock fragments. Additionally, existing studies have not adequately considered the impact of profile rock fragments and rock fragment cover on soil erodibility.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of rock fragment content into soil erodibility factor calculations not yield the expected improvements in mapping accuracy?
Expectation.Answer: Despite the mention of rock fragments' influence on soil erodibility factors in manuals like RUSLE, studies have not fully considered their impact in calculations. This oversight may be due to the lack of a global correction method for calculating soil erodibility factors with rock fragment content, which could affect the expected improvements in mapping accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges of resampling soil property data from a 7.5 arc-second to a 30 arc-second resolution for soil erodibility analysis?
Judgmental.Answer: Resampling soil property data to a coarser resolution might lead to loss of detail, potentially affecting the precision of local soil erodibility estimates. The challenge lies in balancing data manageability with the need for fine-scale accuracy in representing soil characteristics and erosion dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the comprehensiveness of soil datasets like SoilGrids for capturing regional variations in soil erosion influenced by rock fragments?
Judgmental.Answer: Soil datasets like SoilGrids are comprehensive as they include detailed maps of soil properties; however, capturing regional variations in soil erosion influenced by rock fragments requires careful consideration of local heterogeneities and supplementary data to accurately reflect the influence of rock fragments on soil hydrology and erosion rates.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how the presence of rock fragments can alter soil erosion calculations in different environments.
Assertion.Answer: Rock fragments in the soil profile and on the surface can significantly affect soil erosion calculations by altering parameters such as the soil erodibility factor (K) and saturated hydraulic conductivity. The presence of rock fragments can increase soil permeability, reduce water infiltration, and protect soil surfaces from rain impact, thereby modifying erosion rates in varying environments.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why it is challenging to incorporate rock fragment content into global soil erodibility datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Despite the recognition of rock fragments' impact on soil erodibility, there is no established global correction method for incorporating rock fragment content into soil erodibility factors. Challenges include the need for comprehensive data on rock fragment distribution and the complexity of accurately modeling their influence on soil properties at a global level.

Request/Directive.Answer: The methods used to calculate soil erodibility factor (K) include algorithms like USLE-K, RUSLE2-K, EPIC-K, and models based on average geometric particle size. These methods consider soil physical and chemical properties such as particle size, organic matter, structure, and permeability. The challenge in incorporating rock fragment content is that existing studies have not fully explored the impact of profile rock fragments and rock fragment cover on soil erodibility.
